title: feat(router): Allow Route.redirectTo to be a function which returns a…

labels.name: target: minor
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next minor release

labels.name: detected: feature
labels.description: PR contains a feature commit

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
… string or UrlTree

This commit updates the logic around `Route.redirectTo` to enable using a function to create the redirect. This function can return a string, ands acts the same as previous string redirects, or a `UrlTree`, which will act as an absolute redirect.

To be useful, the redirect function needs access to the params and data. Today, developers can access these in their redirect strings, for example `{path: ':id', redirectTo: '/user/:id'}`. Unfortunately, developers only have access to params and data on the _current route_ today in the redirect strings. The params and data in the `RedirectFn` give developers access to anything from the matched parent routes as well. This is done as the same way as param and data aggregation later on (https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/897f014785578d87bc655ea6ae9e113653960f50/packages/router/src/router_state.ts#L236-L278). In order to accomplish this, we inherit params and data while matching, after the `ActivatedRouteSnapshot` is created for the matched route rather than waiting until the end.

The `RedirectFunction` does not return the full
`ActivatedRouteSnapshot` interface. Some things are not accurately known at the route matching phase. For example, resolvers are not run until later, so any resolved title would not be populated. The same goes for lazy loaded components. The is also true for all the snapshots up to the root, so properties that include parents (root, parent, pathFromRoot) are also excluded. And naturally, the full route matching hasn't yet happened so firstChild and children are not available either.

fixes #13373
resolves #28661 (though not for the redirect string - you would return a `UrlTree` from the function)

title: Angular.dev - no clear "deprecated" indicator on API reference.

labels.name: area: docs-infra
labels.description: The angular.io application & related infra. Issues for docs content should use `area: docs`

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

There is no clear indication when an API reference is deprecated.

Example: `provideRoutes` has a clear deprecated label on [angular.io/api/router/provideRoutes](https://angular.io/api/router/provideRoutes) and provides an alternative in the text,  while on [angular.dev/api/router/provideRoutes](https://angular.dev/api/router/provideRoutes) there's only an easy to miss ~~provideRoutes~~ in the codeblock indicating that it's deprecated. No alternative to the deprecated API is provided here. 

### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem

_No response_

### Describe what you were looking for in the documentation

_No response_

### Describe the actions that led you to experience the problem

Direct link to the API reference provided by the Angular Community Discord bot, bypassing the API overview page where a (easy to miss) deprecation indicator is shown.

### Describe what you want to experience that would fix the problem

- A label similar to the type label, indicating that the reference is deprecated would be very useful.
- Mention of an alternative API if available

title: Extend the signature for @defer's when clause
body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

Currently the `when` specifies an imperative condition as an expression that returns a boolean. 

But for more advanced usage of the `when` condition it should also be possible to use a function or method that returns an async value like a promise.

### Proposed solution

A possible signature for the following scenario

```
@defer(when condition()) {...}
```
 would look like this `condition(): boolean | Promise<boolean>`

### Alternatives considered

Observables could also be an option to get a signature that is like `PreloadingStrategy`

labels.name: area: migrations
labels.description: Issues related to `ng update` migrations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
Rather than migrate all in one pass, this now migrates in a separate pass per control flow item plus one for templates at the end. This resolves issues with multiple control flow items on a single element as well as making sure ng-templates are fully migrated before being moved to new locations.

The tradeoff to supporting these cases is performance of the migration.

fixes: #52518

title: Realistic migration path?
body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

upgrade

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Is there a realistic way to upgrade from Angular 12?

It's totally unworkable for *real world* apps outside of Google. (Realistically I am sure it involved a lot of hand-holding inside Google also).


Please don't take this as criticism. It's a **sincere** attempt to inform you of what things are like for a typical app outside Google.

First - with every major release ~30% of all community packages are unsupported. So every single version increment involves removing and replacing multiple packages.

Second - following the upgrade guide and running ng upgrade, it still lands on internally incompatible releases. I suspect the path from older versions became broken at some point since it was current. There's several @angular packages which all have peer-dependencies on each other and following the upgrade guide still cannot get them to compile.

Many migrations fail with errors. When they fail they cannot be retried. There is no "here's how to do this manually" link.


After 12 hours of trying to do the upgrade, there's hundreds of issues, I've manually replaced 6 dead packages, and webpack appears to completely not understand CSS any longer. It's not realistic to open dozens of individual issues.


I believe this is the typical experience of an Angular user trying to upgrade. But the reason this never reaches your attention is people don't make this kind of post - they just quiet quit (and stop maintaining their packages).

If I upgrade React or Vue, nothing breaks. And it's one package. You can import parts from that package.

For the (many) people who simply cannot upgrade, is there some realistic advice (create a new app with x recommended settings, and try and copy things component-by-component, fixing issues as they arise?)


I think realistically without the engineering resources & direct support which Google gets - most people are realistically unable to do the upgrades.

Maybe there's some tooling to help people start with a clean-sheet app and copy & upgrade their components? The current path isn't just too painful it's flatly not possible.



Please take this in the spirit it's intended: firstly as a notice of what it's really like for a long-term user, and secondly as a plea for some kind of help. It would be really nice to be on V17 as it looks super nice. At a minimum you should consider surveying what %age of people succeed in their migration path. I suspect I am the common case & the biggest driver of abandonment on the framework is that upgrading is not possible.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

NA

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
Hundreds...

Failing migrations that cannot be retried. Peer dependencies between internal Angular packages which cannot resolve. Imports between Angular packages which are broken at every step. Webpack complaining that there's no loader which can understand CSS. And ofc the expected breaking changes.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular 12 and upwards.
```


### Anything else?

NA

title: RouterStateSnapshot.url does not include complete sub-path anymore
body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

router

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

After updating from Angular 14 to 16 and refactoring guards to functional guards, there is a new behavior of RouterStateSnapshot.url.

Prior, the entire sub path was included in the property (/download/start-download), now only the last part is included (start-download). 

Angular 14:

title: angular.dev: Concerns about new color palette
body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

Angular always had a recognisable color for its self positioning. We had blue for React, green for Vue, orange for Svelte ... and **red** for Angular. Every one could say that this is Angular just by looking at its logo. Now I can't say which color Angular has because I don't understand which color it has (no, really. Is it red, purple, pink? :))

I am suggesting to keep its main color the same as it was before without any (red, pink, purple, etc) gradients. I think it would help to keep some succession to its previous versions and continue providing strong association with framework.

title: feat(core): support TypeScript 5.3

labels.name: action: review
labels.description: The PR is still awaiting reviews from at least one requested reviewer

labels.name: area: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to `ngc`, Angular's template compiler

labels.name: target: minor
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next minor release

labels.name: detected: feature
labels.description: PR contains a feature commit

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
Updates the repo to support TypeScript 5.3 and resolve any issues. Fixes include:
* Updating usages of TS compiler APIs to match their new signatures.
* In TS 5.3 negative numbers are represented as `PrefixUnaryExpression` instead of `NumericExpression`. These changes update all usages to account for it since passing a negative number into the old APIs results in a runtime error.

title: Defer syntax doesn't create lazy chunks when component imported from a barrel

labels.name: area: core
labels.description: Issues related to the framework runtime

labels.name: core: defer
labels.description: Issues related to @defer blocks.

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When using the new defer syntax with component imported from a barrel file (like a `index.ts` with re-exports) the expected lazy-loaded chunks are not created. Instead, the component is included in the main bundle, which contradicts the intended lazy loading behavior.

### Steps to Reproduce

- Create two components
- Create index.ts file which re-exports them both
- Import both components to the parent using index.ts file
- Add both components to the imports section of parent component
- Use both components in the template
- Wrap one of them to defer block

### Expected behavior

After the build process, the dist directory should contain a lazy-loaded chunk that includes the component wrapper to the defer block.

### Actual Behavior

No lazy-loaded chunks are created. Both components is bundled in the main chunk.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/mdafanasev/angular-defer-barrel-file-issue

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 17.0.0-rc.3
Node: 18.18.2
Package Manager: npm 9.7.2
OS: linux x64

Angular: 17.0.0-rc.2
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1700.0-rc.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular   17.0.0-rc.3
@angular-devkit/core            17.0.0-rc.3
@angular-devkit/schematics      17.0.0-rc.3
@angular/cli                    17.0.0-rc.3
@schematics/angular             17.0.0-rc.3
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.2.2
zone.js                         0.14.2
```

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request? core ### Description https://vuejs.org/guide/components/slots.html#scoped-slots I know Angular has something similar to Vue slots in content projection, however, those cannot take arguments like Vue's scoped slots. It would be great if Angular could support scoped slots. ### Proposed solution Something like (if A is a component that accepts slots, and B is using A) ``` A: B:

{{slotProps.var}}

``` Again this is only a suggestion ### Alternatives considered None as far as I'm aware.

title: New docs too clicky - including most important get started

labels.name: area: docs-infra
labels.description: The angular.io application & related infra. Issues for docs content should use `area: docs`

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Description of the Issue:

I've encountered navigation and visibility issues on the Angular documentation website, which seem to make the user experience less intuitive, particularly on mobile devices.

### URL of the Affected Page:

[Angular.dev](https://angular.dev)

### Detailed Feedback:

1. **Visibility of Key Information:**
   - The critical command `ng new` is not immediately visible. For comparison, the NX documentation features their equivalent command prominently on the homepage. A direct link to the [guides](https://angular.dev/overview) and [reference](https://angular.dev/api) sections is provided, but the formatting makes it easy to overlook.

2. **General Navigation Concerns:**
   - On mobile, navigating the documentation is cumbersome. After selecting a menu item, the menu closes, and reopening it is necessary to continue to sub-sections, which is not user-friendly.

3. **Documentation Flow:**
   - The "Start Coding" section redirects to a tutorial, which is unexpected. It would be more logical to present `ng new` at this stage.
   - The tutorials page at [First App Tutorial](https://angular.dev/tutorials/first-app) does not mention the `ng new` command. Additionally, it's unclear whether installing Angular globally is still the recommended practice.

4. **Tutorial Navigation:**
   - The dropdown menus in the tutorial section feel clunky. A dual-mode navigation system, allowing users to switch between tutorial steps and direct access to topics, could enhance the experience.

I appreciate the sleek design of the site, but it seems there are opportunities to refine the UX to better support developers. This is a subjective perspective, and I apologize for the brevity of my feedback. I am open to discussing these points further and would be happy to contribute to improving the user experience.

body: ### Describe the problem that you experienced Upon visiting the Angular website at https://angular.dev/roadmap, you'll notice an array of intriguing options to explore. title: Supercharge Angular devtools with integration into the Elements tab and allow RxJS to show current values
body: ### Is this a bug report or a feature request? - [ ] Bug Report - [X] Feature Request ### Description [Feature Request only] One of the reasons I still prefer [Angular State Inspector](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/angular-state-inspector/nelkodgfpddgpdbcjinaaalphkfffbem) over Angular Devtools is that its inside the Elements tab as a tab next to styles/computed/layout. Being there allows me to easily click the DOM elements and see both their final styles as the properties that are bound to the elements, the state. I would love it if Angular Devtools enabled a similar view that is able to be closer to my code. Another thing that annoys me when inspecting is that RxJS observables, mainly those using async pipes, are difficult to view what they currently hold. Of course I could work around this by logging the item to console and adding functions there to log it, or put break points in my code to see whats what. But I feel thats kinda overkill and not really necessary what helps me quickly view how data flows through my app (especially if you are finding a side-effect of a component that transformed a value that you are looking where it was changed like that). A better integration on RxJS would help junior devs a lot and I think its the main thing missing from devtools. Aside being near what I see when I right click an element to inspect it. Simple state overview on a certain element from angular state inspector: Pretty useless subscription when inspecting an observable in angular devtools: ### Proposed solution [Feature Request only] -Be closer to the regular element inspector, allowing me to quickly see what data these elements hold and what their current value is. -Improve compatibility with RxJS for devtools to not just show operator and source (where operator somehow opens lift.js and source is either an endless list of other operator/source children or it shows _subscribe and when clicking the (...) it just goes to where the observable class was defined) Because what does a dev want to inspect? Actual values, not just the structure of the framework. Because that only answers half the question of "why does it do what it does". ### Alternatives considered [Feature Request only] Of course I can keep using Angular State Inspector but it doesn't seem to be maintained (august 2021 was the last one) while still being a valuable tool for Angular devs.

body:
Includes a couple of minor fixes to the control flow migration that came up when I was putting together https://github.com/angular/components/pull/28058.

### fix(migrations): handle comma-separated syntax in ngFor
This is something that came up when running the script against the Components repo. The `ngFor` syntax can be delimited either by semicolons or by commas, but the migration only accounted for commas.

### fix(migrations): account for separator characters inside strings
Fixes that the control flow migrations wasn't accounting for separator characters used inside string literals.

title: control flow: migration does not preserve i18n attribute on ng-template

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Hi.
This code:

```
<ng-container *ngIf="cond; else testTpl">
bla bla
</ng-container>
   
<ng-template #testTpl i18n="@@test_key">Some text</ng-template>
```

Got migrated to this:

```
@if (cond) {
  bla bla
} @else {
  Some text
}
```

I guess this is not fixable, because of strange setup with i18n attribute on ng-template. But maybe consider migrating this code to <ng-container i18n=""></ng-container

title: fix(compiler): ng-template directive invoke twice at the root of control flow

labels.name: action: merge
labels.description: The PR is ready for merge by the caretaker

labels.name: area: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to `ngc`, Angular's template compiler

labels.name: target: rc
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next release-candidate

milestone.title: v17-final
milestone.description: PRs which need to land by v17 final

body:
Discovered this while validating #52414 against Angular Material. We were projecting `<ng-template>` nodes at the root of `@if` and `@for` with the `ng-template` tag name which enables directive matching and applies the directive to the control flow node.

These changes fix the issue by never passing along the `ng-template` tag name.

body: This commit removes the `load` event listener once it has fired within the `ImagePerformanceWarning`. The `load` event listener prevents the zone stuff from being garbage collected in development mode when debugging microfrontend applications that may be destroyed multiple times.

title: refactor(http): return chunks with progress event
body:
With `reportProgress:true`, it is now possible to read the individual chunks in a `HttpDownloadProgressEvent` when using the `FetchBackend`.

fixes #52494
